notes: Working titles for this story were Wasteland and The Robots of Ravalox.
Despite the change to the 'Doctor Who Theme' arrangement, the title sequence introduced in The Twin Dilemma remained unchanged for the season.
Beginning with this story, Doctor Who returned to its original 25-minute episode format, which it retained for the remainder of the original series.
The filmed insert that begins part one of a special effects sequence involving the TARDIS and the space station would be the last shot-on-film footage made for Doctor Who until the 1996 TV movie.
Colin Baker felt that the money could have spent elsewhere.
Graeme Harper was asked to direct, but was not free.
Beginning with this story, all exteriors would be recorded using Outside Broadcast video, rather than film as had usually been the practice for the previous 22 years.
The use of OB for exteriors would continue for the remainder of the original series, until its end in 1989.
In an interview in Doctor Who Magazine 448, Timelash author Glen McCoy said that he came up with the idea of the Doctor being put on trial.
Joan Sims is said to have disliked her stint on the series.
Colin Baker admitted that the script wasn't the greatest and didn't like the "junkyard, railyard" remarks, either.

Roger Brierley was originally supposed to deliver his lines as Drathro while inhabiting the robot costume constructed by the BBC Visual Effects Department. However, he found the outfit claustrophobic and unwieldy, and he soon became adamant that his involvement be limited to providing Drathro's dialogue.
Robert Holmes was in ill-health when he wrote the script.
Eric Saward thought that he could write good dialogue.

in_universe_mythology: The Free worship the Earth god Haldren
The black light converter functions as its totem
real_world_cultural_references: Glitz asks the Doctor if he, as a Time Lord, has a ring or a magic lamp to rub
When the Doctor is forbidden to look upon the Immortal, he jokes about the risk of being turned into a pillar of salt
The three sacred books of Marb Station are Moby-Dick by Herman Melville, The Water Babies by Charles Kingsley, and UK Habitats of the Canadian Goose by H.M. Stationery Office

continuity_notes: The Doctor believes he is still Lord President of Gallifrey, until the Inquisitor informs him that he has since been deposed for leaving the office vacant too long.

The Inquisitor claims the Doctor has already "been on trial already for offences of this nature". The Valeyard contends that the High Council were "too lenient" with the sentence that resulted from that trial.
Glitz uses the phrase "Five rounds, rapid ought to do the trick", which Brigadier Lethbridge-Stewart used when directing UNIT soldiers to shoot Bok.

plot.plot_summary: The Doctor is summoned before the High Council of Time Lords to stand trial for the charges of harmful interference to the course of events during his space-time excursions, which have threatened the sanctity of the universe. His prosecuting attorney, a sinister Time Lord known as the Valeyard, begins a crusade against the Doctor's life with the motive of painting him out to be a villainous renegade. The Valeyard's first movement against the Doctor is to review his past interactions on the planet Ravolox, where he and his companion Peri met the morally grey Sabalom Glitz and a tyrannical robot stalking the world's desolated landscape. However, Ravolox holds a terrible truth in the far reaches of its ruins, while the Doctor's trial has its own fair share of startling twists and turns.

The Doctor and Peri arrive on the planet Ravolox, which is virtually identical to Earth. They encounter the morally ambiguous Sabalom Glitz and his associate Dibber, who are plotting to sabotage a powerful robot called Drathro. The Doctor is put on trial by the Time Lords, with the Valeyard prosecuting him. Through the Matrix, the Valeyard shows the Doctor's actions on Ravolox, where he discovers that the planet is in fact a devastated Earth moved across space. Glitz and Dibber try to steal Drathro's technology, while the Doctor attempts to stop Drathro from destroying the entire universe. In the end, the Doctor is able to prevent the catastrophic explosion, but the Valeyard warns that he has more evidence to present against the Doctor.
